author: Jack Aylmer
title: Underwater turbines in France could provide energy for up to 8 million
text:
[Jack Aylmer]
UNDERWATER TURBINES MAY HELP FRANCE PRODUCE ENERGY FOR MILLIONS OF PEOPLE.
AFTER RECEIVING NEARLY 34 MILLION DOLLARS IN FUNDING FROM THE EUROPEAN UNION-
THE NH1 TIDAL PROJECT WILL BE BUILT OFF THE COAST OF NORMANDY-
WHERE THE OCEAN CURRENT IS AMONG THE STRONGEST IN THE WORLD.
THIS INITIATIVE WILL BEGIN WITH A PILOT FARM COMPRISED OF FOUR UNDERWATER TURBINES-
WHICH HARNESS THE FLOW OF THE SEA TO GENERATE ELECTRICITY-
PRODUCING 34 GIGAWATT-HOURS ANNUALLY-
ENOUGH TO MEET THE NEEDS OF 15,000 PEOPLE.
BUT THERE ARE PLANS TO EVENTUALLY ADD MORE TURBINES-
INCREASING THAT POWER OUTPUT TO AS MUCH AS 18 TERAWATT-HOURS-
SUPPLYING ENERGY FOR 8 MILLION PEOPLE.
AS A RESULT OF THIS ENDEAVOR, NEARLY 58,000 TONS OF GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS ARE EXPECTED TO BE AVOIDED-
EQUIVALENT TO TAKING MORE THAN 13,500 GAS-POWERED CARS OFF THE ROAD FOR A YEAR.
HOWEVER, CONCERNS STILL REMAIN ABOUT THE PROJECT’S ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT-
WITH SOME CONSERVATIONISTS SAYING MARINE ECOSYSTEMS COULD BE DISRUPTED.
DEVELOPERS ARE PUSHING BACK AGAINST THESE CLAIMS-
SAYING NH1 TURBINES, INSTALLED AROUND 125 FEET DEEP, HAVE BEEN DESIGNED TO OPERATE WITH MINIMAL IMPACT ON SURROUNDING WILDLIFE.
THEY ALSO POINT TO A SIMILAR TIDAL FARM OFF THE COAST OF SCOTLAND-
WHERE MARINE LIFE REPORTEDLY ADAPTED TO THESE STRUCTURES, EVEN USING THEM AS NEW HABITAT SPACES.
THE NH1 PROJECT IS SET TO START PRODUCING ELECTRICITY BY 2028-
AND FUTURE ADDITIONS TO THIS TIDAL FARM WILL SEE 85 NEW TURBINES DEPLOYED ANNUALLY.
FOR STRAIGHT ARROW NEWS, I’M JACK AYLMER.

author: Europa Press
title: Retrasos generalizados en el aeropuerto de Palma por el mal tiempo
text: El [aeropuerto de Palma](/etiqueta/Aeropuerto+de+Palma.html?utm_source=Inline-tag&utm_medium=internal) sufre retrasos generalizados, tanto en salidas como en llegadas, por el mal tiempo. Según la información de Aena consultada por Europa Press, los retrasos son de media de unos 60 minutos. Retrasos generalizados en el aeropuerto de Palma por el mal tiempo Son de media de unos 60 minutos El También en Noticias [Aviso de la Aemet: la DANA se reactiva y las lluvias serán muy fuertes en Mallorca](/noticias/local/2024/10/31/2268065/lluvias-fuertes-mallorca-dana-reactiva-segun-aemet.html) [Palma se pone en alerta: Cort cerrará los cementerios por el temporal](/sucesos/ultimas/2024/10/31/2268377/cort-cerrara-cementerios-desde-horas-del-viernes-hasta-lunes-por-temporal.html) [Casi 40 kilómetros de torrentes de Mallorca presentan un riesgo significativo de inundación](/sucesos/ultimas/2024/10/31/2267845/inundaciones-mallorca-prevencion-planificacion-casi-kilometros-peligro.html) [Palma, el lugar más peligroso de Mallorca en riesgo de inundaciones](/noticias/local/2024/11/01/2268437/tiempo-baleares-palma-lugar-mas-peligroso-mallorca-riesgo-inundaciones.html) [La tragedia de Valencia agrava el temor en Mallorca ante la aproximación de la DANA](/noticias/local/2024/11/01/2268313/lluvias-fuertes-mallorca-tragedia-valencia-agrava-temor-mallorca-ante-aproximacion-dana.html) Sin comentarios De momento no hay comentarios.

author: VNExplorer
title: Art stolen by Nazis during World War II returned to original owner's family
text:
NEW YORK — Two art pieces stolen by Nazis during World War II were returned to the family of their original owners Friday.
It’s part of an ongoing effort by the Manhattan district attorney’s office to retrieve stolen pieces.
Egon Schiele’s “Girl with Black Hair” from 1911 and “Portrait of a Man” from 1917 have both been safely returned over a century later to their rightful owners — the family of Fritz Grunbaum, an Austrian-Jewish cabaret performer who had the works of art in his collection before they were stolen by the Nazis.
“Today, you have shown the very moral courage in taking action. History will remember you for this,” said Paul Reif, Grunbaum’s great-great nephew.
Reif stood alongside his father, Timothy, Grunbaum’s great nephew.
Grunbaum was captured by the Nazis in 1938 and had these pieces, along with at least 80 others by the same artist, in his collection.
The Manhattan district attorney’s antiquities trafficking unit seized the pieces from art galleries along with eight others last September.
“We can never forget the horror experienced by Mr. Grunbaum and the millions of other Jewish victims of the Holocaust, and these pieces provide an important lens in which to tell their story,” District Attorney Alvin Bragg said.
The Reifs saw these works of art in person for the first time Friday. When they’re auctioned off, proceeds from these pieces and the others returned will go towards underrepresented artists as a way to continue Grunbaum’s legacy.
“I would just offer my words of admiration and thanks for setting an example for me to follow as an artist,” Paul Reif said.
Efforts are underway to return one more piece that’s currently at the Art Institute of Chicago, and oral arguments for that take place April 3.
